For anyone considering a community college, here's a few reasons why you SHOULD go: 1) You'll save a lot of money, especially if you don't know what you wanna do and you wanna experiment with different classes 2) They are generally closer to home and don't have on campus housing, saving you even more money 3) Some still have sports teams and mascots, meaning you still get a fun college experience! 4) It's a good transition step from highschool to university life 5) The classes are smaller and you can get a lot more one on one help 6) It's a community college so you will learn to work with all kinds of people; plenty of nontraditional students go to a community college 7) Plenty still offer financial aid and scholarships, meaning you can put those towards the university of your dreams! 8) A lot of community colleges offer two year programs which are PERFECT for people who want to get into the work force a lot quicker. .... I hope this helped some people who might be on the fence. Happy learning all ❤️

Feeling bad about yourself is about the worst thing you can do and is NOT the only outcome of the 'big fish, small pond' effect. I've interviewed plenty of job applicants over the past 15 years or so and this includes graduates of places like Angelo State University, Appalacian State and Evergreen State to places like Princeton, Yale, Harvard, UCLA, Penn State and so forth.

To be perfectly honest, it's clear that most (not all) of the graduates of flagship and so-called prestigious Universities are entitled jerk wads who think they are owed let's say a $90,000 job, with a complete range of benefits, without having any legitimate workplace experience (aside from the usual mumbo jumbo that is on 90% of college graduates resumes at about age 22) while the typical high school graduate or someone who graduated from a relatively unknown University tend to not come with the unreasonable salary demands or the attitude problems.

This isn't to say that there aren't some stinkers in the latter group but that they just don't seem to think that they are as entitled without earning the merit of said entitlement. It seems like high school graduates, veterans, and those who went through a community college pipeline or otherwise graduated from a smaller or relatively unknown college or university also are willing to actually prove themselves in the workplace for the most part.

All in all, I've learned to find gems among the rubbish and we have a process in place now that essentially weeds out the knuckleheads before they even show up to a job interview which is almost like letting the competition sift through the garbage pile while we take Paris by storm figuratively speaking.

The bottom line is that college today doesn't really mean crap in the workforce. What it does mean is that someone got suckered into believing that it does.

I can take a high school graduate, who maybe didn't give a flying duck fart in high school, and train them to earn say $45K a year working just part time and they won't have the baggage of debt that college graduates come bearing. And the very next year, there's a whole slew of high school graduates who are looking for something better than restaurant or warehouse work.

The truth is that college today isn't teaching the next generation what they need to know to be successful. They're just scamming them under the pretense of education while conning them out of tens of thousands of dollars.

This video perfectly explains the reason that affirmative action policies are more harmful than they are good. For example, when you create a quota [minimum] for how many black students Harvard, for instance, needs to accept per year, you're dooming most of them to failure. Those black students are being admitted, in the case of affirmative action, ONLY because of the color of their skin—NOT because of their intelligence or grades. When you do that, those students are now at the bottom of their class, become demotivated, drop out (or fail) and not only don't find employment thereafter, but have wasted years of their lives and tens of thousands of dollars. If you, however, let those same students be admitted to a college/university to which they've EARNED admission, then they have the opportunity to be at the top of their class, and graduate with awards, honours, etc. Now, I'm not saying that black people aren't intelligent—there surely are plenty of highly intelligent black people who've left their marks on society, but affirmative action mainly aims (actually, aimed, but it was never ended after its initial intended purpose was served decades ago) to help blacks (and other minorities) REGARDLESS of their grades, effort, etc. They gain admission, again, solely due to their skin color, and that's not only not fair to the students who worked their asses off to earn admission, but it's also a disservice to the black (and minority) students who are being placed in a school that leaves them with their heads barely above the water, and doomed to fail. In life, it's critical, in order to succeed and progress, to surround yourself with people who are smarter than you, but it's still better to graduate at the top of ones class with ease than not at all and be destined for not only failure, but victimhood, debt, depression, poverty, etc.

Think of college like a car.

You have cheap cars and you have expensive cars. The cheap cars may not have navigation, heated seats, or an auto safety system, but they'll get you from point A to point B at a far cheaper rate as long as you have the drive and skills to push it along your path.

An expensive car might have a plethora of luxuries that lower the risk of getting from point A to point B, as well as (perhaps) some advanced driving skills, but you'll have less money for gas on top of the money you have to pay back for your car. In either case you're likely to end up at point B; in one scenario, you are lacking some experience but not money, and in the other you have more experience but less money to do the things you wish to do at your destination.

There are so many problems with the statistics you presented in this video, likely from your blatant misunderstanding of most of the statistics.

1) The SAT math score chart's percentages are not saying graduation RATES for that certain score group, they are saying how many graduates HAVE that certain score. Harvard's graduation rate is in the high 90s. All that chart is saying about Harvard is that most of its graduates have high SAT math scores, not that they will fail to get a degree...

2) The comparison effect is a fair point, and it certainly may affect your self-perception, but that has nothing to do with the purpose of going to a college, which is to learn, develop, and utilize your learning and development to do something in your life, whether it be a career, devotion to research, community service, etc. One's self-confidence is also a highly variable thing, and some people might not be affected at all by this effect.

3) When you discuss STEM and dropping out of STEM, I'm assuming that you're also completely misinterpreting the statistics. Perhaps STEM graduation rate decreases as SAT score increases, but that's almost certainly because a better school will have a notably harder STEM curriculum, as the course rigor, faculty, and requirements are all at a considerably higher level. This might force prospective STEM majors to switch majors to something that they can handle, or that suits their interests more, as many 17-year-olds who think they want to major in mathematics can be quickly disillusioned once they step out of AP Calculus and into high-level theoretical mathematics.

Furthermore, there is no way that overall GRADUATION RATE decreases as SAT scores raise, look at any top 50 college vs. any bottom 50 college and try to tell me that the top has a lower graduation rate.... Even if this were the case, it could also easily be explainable by the fact that worse schools have considerably lower course rigor than harder schools, so that its lower-performing students can graduate at all...

4) What you're trying to bring up about economists and research papers is not only horrendously wrong, but it's extremely disrespectful to the graduates from those top 5 schools, who you literally called "failures in their fields". First of all, that study does not say the 30 worst schools, it says NON-TOP-30 schools.... (https://www.insidehighered.com/news/2014/11/19/study-says-research-output-overwhelming-majority-economics-phds-low) the 30 worst schools would not be producing any economics research papers in highly reputable publication journals at all. That study shows that the top 5 schools are, in fact, considerably better than the non-top-30s.

Plus, of all of the things you could have used to attempt to quantify your point, Economic research from PhDs is quite possible the absolute worst, as it is a GRADUATE school field, which is clearly not what you are talking about in the rest of the video.

I have a cousin who went to the university at the state capital but he doesn't have as good a job as his younger brother who went to our local university. My brother went to our local university and got into dental school and now he's a dentist. I went to our local university and I graduated magna cum laude and I'm working at my university. We didn't have to go so far away to get a good education or a degree and we were prepared for what we are doing. You learn along the way what works for you. Sadly, my university doesn't have the masters degree program I want so I have to go away, but even then I feel ready because my university prepared me well. A lot of my classmates have gone to other schools before coming back to our local university because they failed out or thought it was too hard. So I'm not saying people will do horrible when they leave fresh out of high school, but I'm saying we lack the maturity to handle so much independence university life gives us. I think it has to do with the level of maturity you have, too. I knew I wasn't ready to leave home and my university was a good choice because my brother went there and got his degree and also got into the school he wanted. I had my proof that it was a competitive and decent school. I was a great student in high school, but in university, I learned the hard way that I had to study long and hard. Its not easy, you have to work for it. But its manageable once you find what works for you and that could take some time to figure out. I don't think top schools are a waste of time, but why go so far away when you have a good school right next to you? People here take it for granted but they always come back to our university. So it isn't the school, but rather the person and their commitment and maturity. At least that's what I've gathered over the years.

Top schools are a bit like employment agencies bcs of contacts that emerge -- professors, internships and peers.  Contacts land jobs.  A better approach for students: Gain entry into those schools which are experts in your given field of interest.  Example: Should MIT say no, Georgia Tech is one of the best engineering schools in the USA.   Should both institutions turn you down, get a 2-year at a good tech college.  Your initiative and constancy will show well on your record should you decide to reapply.  Either way, the future of new jobs is in the vast field -- and mind-boggling alternatives -- of "technical" degrees which typically include paid mentorships.  Six figures are frequent.  Research your options.

In my opinion, getting to "the best" universities only matters depending on your career plans for the future. If you want to be a doctor, lawyer, artist, etc, you can go to a regular college that doesn't cost very much. However, if you have plans to opening up a new business, or company, I suggest you go to a more expensive university, which is usually popular for having "clever people" in it.

It's not because of the popularity of the place, rather the people you could come across and get to know. Which is highly important if you plan to do business for your future. Popular universities are known for the clever students, so attending it might give you the benefit of gaining associates for your career future.

Sage Advice Below: Do this and do not stray. How the individual defines success matters. Do publications matter in grand scheme of things? Nope. Make no mistake college is important but in high-insight the University plastered on the front of diploma doesn't matter as much. I can't speak for other people but I look at the quality of the work not the quantity. Here's my humble advice for people in high school and college. Do the best you can. I don't mean that in a corny way but with sincerity. In everything you do regardless of the task-<del>put your best into it. I mean everything from folding your laundry too, sweeping the floor, too how you talk to your teachers and professors. Get a part-time job and do take pride in even a lowly position. Be respectful to everyone even the janitor. Be fifty minutes early for everything for which you have an appointment. Develop your morals and learn from your blunders. Ask your professors and teachers how you can do better. Ask your peers that do great to tag along and learn from them. Don't fall victim to sloth or over exert yourself on trivial matters. Research areas of interest to you then attend meetings, conferences and seminars with questions in hand.  Be friendly and inquisitive about things your actually like-</del> shake a lot of hands. Write down a lot of names. Be a collector of certificates preferably in things that interest you. Lastly, getting into or not getting into a college of your choice isn't the end of the world. Use the cards you have and build them up. I didn't make it into college from high school. I joined the military and put five good years in before be injured. I went to a community college, did well and got an AS paralegal degree. Went to a rather lowly University and got a BA in political science--something that interests me. During those years doing paralegal work with pay and pro bono. Made friends and built solid relationships with people. Followed the advice that I've written here. I am a 3L Law Student now and already have skills that the others don't. Even career offers at large firms and I haven't even taken the BAR exam. Long story short never give up! I was C student in the beginning with a lot of issues. After, my injuries I was told to just except the fact that I wasn't going to be able to work or make it through college. Never ever give up!

This is me in my IB classes. I am definitely not the best in IB. I have math Classes with Freshman and I am a Junior, guaranteed I am in Algebra 2 which is the normal math class, but IB is anything but normal. I am the only Juniors in my IB school who is taking Algebra 2 because everyone else starts out as a freshman taking Geometry or Algebra 2.  In my Freshmen year of IB, our Algebra one Class had only 15 kids in it, as we advanced to sophomores that number was greatly reduced because some dropped IB or e-schooled Geometry in other to advance to the same field as the other IB Students. I did not do that. Moving onto Junior year today, the remaining 5 people who were in my Algebra 1 class dropped IB, making me the Only junior in IB taking Algebra 2. I feel incredibly stupid every day in a class filled with Freshmen and Sophomores who consistently get better grades than I on our Math tests and quizzes.  My situation is so unique that when we planned our IB diploma exam schedules, they had to find an alternate for me because they were so surprised that I made it this far. I am now signed up to take Math SL instead of IB Precalculus, IB Calculus, BC Calculus or AB Calculus, which is what everyone else in my grade is taking. They are all incredibly surprised that I made it this far, and so am I because I seriously thought of dropping out so many times. Math SL is considered the Math class for dumb kids, but I know I am anything but dumb. Sometimes when you are surrounded by incredibly brilliant minds, it is hard for you to consider yourself smart also. I take IB classes and I have never failed a class before, I am intelligent compared to the average non-IB students. Somedays though I find it hard to think like that, because i consistently fell like a small fish in a big pond.

Well, I'll tell you from my experience, a degree in general can put you in a better position to receive promotions for jobs you may not be fit for, but it won't guarantee job safety or performance, depending on the industry. It also can be the part of your resume that allows you to keep moving up with in your career. I've worked in the Banking industry for years, and after dropping out of my first year in college, I started working as a temporary part time Teller for Wells Fargo Bank at the age of 18, making 11.36 per hour. I wasn't sure where I was headed in life at that time, all I knew was that I was nervous and intimidated on my first day on the job working for Wells Fargo, after finishing training. I caught on very quickly, and realized that it's not only about what you know, it's also about who you are, that determines how effective you can be. I realized my personality and ability to connect with people socially, was a key to a great future. Banking, is all about Sales and Customer Service. I outperformed Bank representatives in the same area, that were full time (40 hrs), while I was only a temporary 17 hour Teller. I outperformed reps that had been with the company for years, with strong educational backgrounds. After 6 months, I was promoted to a Junior Banker at the age of 18!! Continued to soar, promoted again after 9 months to a Licensed Personal Banker and eventually a Premier Banker 2. BUT! I hit a roadblock. All because I didn't have a degree. After years of success and learning from some of the best Bankers Wells Fargo has to offer, I decided it was time to take on Wall St. but unfortunately, one of the requirements of becoming a Financial Adviser (Stock Broker), I had to have a degree in accounting/economics. Even though I have years of experience, I was ineligible for the position due to a lack of education. Wasn't even able to apply. So to answer this video, yes it does matter what school you go to and it matters what degree you receive.

Absolute flop of a video. The measurements and statistics used are completely irrelevant and misleading. The rate of graduation or number of published papers has little significance to whether your "school matters." There are hundreds of other things that can more relevantly be used to measure whether your school matters such as rates of employment at different brackets of income, or businesses founded and operating more than 10 years after their founding. If 100% of students graduate but none of them can get a job, the school probably sucks. If >20% graduate but >80% of the total (including those that didn't graduate) get jobs at income levels higher than average US household income, or start successful businesses (as is likely case for all the colleges mentioned in the list of top schools), well there may be something to be said about that. Stop poisoning people's minds with misleading irrelevant information. Credible sources such as Forbes or Entrepreneur Magazine or the US World News actually publishes this information annually. Do some research yourself on LinkedIn, Monster.com, US Census data, or talk to your neighbors and friends.

I recently graduated high school with an average GPA of 3.8, an ACT score of 22 (only took it once), and a class rank of 20 out of 148. The GPA is stellar, but the ACT score is just average. My anxiety, accompanied by an inability to adequately manage time most likely led to my average test score. I always felt that they never gave you enough time to finish those standardized tests. For instance, when I took mine in March of last year, I did not complete any of the four tests. In addition, my highest score was on the shortest test, science. I would advise anyone planning on retaking a standardized test to skip a question after 30 seconds of pondering. Also, if there is only a short amount of time left, and you have yet to complete a column, fill in the bubbles with a consistent pattern.

In retrospect, I should have better prepared for the ACT. However, I had known that the college I was applying to only needed a ACT score of 18, which is most certainly feasible. Now, I am a freshman attending a small, state university. It's not University of Illinois, University of Michigan, or any other large state college; however, it is a university. I want to be a web developer, so obtaining a bachelor's degree is advised, but most of your skills as a developer cannot be obtained by any university. The field evolves far too quickly for colleges to keep up.

The thesis of the video is based on the assumption that your SAT score is an accurate measure of your potential to be meaningful contributor (or even a good student). The authors don't consider the possibility that those who go to the "best schools" have some artificial advantage that boosts their SAT score. It's far more likely that a similar percentage of students in any population have what it takes to do well in college (regardless of their SAT score) than that those who don't do well in college but had relatively high SAT scores should just be more confident.

Graduation rate is not the same as how smart a student is. If a student graduates in a high percentile from any college or university it can be the result of them being smart or taking easier classes to earn better grades.
You also compared the success rates from better and worse schools at different percentiles to show a close comparison which can add to evidence of people in worse schools having less successful futures than people from MIT, Yale, etc.

I went to a community college, then a state university for my bachelors in mechanical engineering. At my company, many of my coworkers come from some pretty great schools like WPI, RPI, and i've heard that we have some older guys from MIT. To me this is enough proof that going to a fancy school won't necessarily make you any better off. At my university a lot of companies sponsored projects with the school, and donate a lot of money to the school. Some of these companies have higher ups who graduated from the school and want to give back, and may even prioritize you if you're from that school. Because of this its pretty common to see companies with an unusually high percentage of people from a couple of local schools.

As long as your school has a decent program you should be fine, and will save yourself tens of thousands of dollars if you go to a university instead of a fancy school. It probably depends a lot on what major you're going for, what kind of job you want, etc., but i'm confident anyone with a lot of determination could pull off a great career coming out of an average school.

Interesting scientific study but...
A lot of studies tend to arrive at a limited number of conclusions based on a small set of criteria. In the real world there are a lot more variables.
Several assumptions in the video:
1. People who produced published works are smarter. To a degree but you can also include people who published works outside their field of specialty such as someone who writes fiction novels such as JRR Tolkien who wrote "The Lord of the Rings" and JK Rowling who wrote the "Harry Potter" series. These are creative people. Those who have published works may be smarter in 1 way but there are those who are doctors & lawyers who are happy with their careers and manage to bring enough to enjoy vacations year after year.
2. People who graduated from top schools are more likely to get good jobs. Refer back to Dave Thomas who founded the Wendy's burger chain. When his business became a success, he was on TV doing a commercial telling kids to stay in school at the time when he was a "dropout". He went back and finished high school. But it is unlikely the extra year or 2 of education would contribute anything to his annual profits except a sense of personal accomplishment. So... Bill Gates is a dropout too, isn't he? With his own MS business he is the richest man in the world. In life, working for other people with even a fixed 9-5 hour is not the only way to make a living.

This video presents a lot of misleading stats.

TLDR: This video is pretty much clickbait

The percentages of graduation shown were of student two stayed at the same school. The bottom third of the top school students didn't just drop out and quit their education. They probably transferred to become the top third of an easier school. While it's likely that students who drop out of mediocre or community colleges quit their education all together.

The only statistic of success in the "real world" is by publications in economics. Now that's a very specific measure and misleading. First, the quality of publication matters. Just because you published a paper doesn't mean it was published in a top journal. Second, there are many who choose not to publish and go straight into a salary job. More academic minded students will stay in the academics to publish papers. Just because you don't publish doesn't mean you are a failure in your field, I'm sure they are still making a ton of money.

What would be been a better measure would be comparing income after 10 years of admission to the school of choice. I will bet the bottom third of students who choose to go to top schools make significantly more than the top third of an average school. And I can only suspect that the maker of this video found that info but didn't want to include it in his video because it doesn't support his stance.

Among four-year schools, this is true, but since the thumbnail mentioned community college, I'll warn the students here...

If you're trying to get into a field where there's serious job demand--in my case, that's programming--you should be aware that community colleges probably don't have the best teachers, and the few really good teachers they may have are going to have packed schedules. Most graduate-degreed programmers in my area are doing something more interesting and better-paid than lecturing to a bunch of 19-year-olds at eight in the morning.

Four-year schools are at least bigger and better known, so you'll have better luck there. Teachers can make or break your experience, so be careful where you decide to go.

If you're studying psychology or something, though, you don't need to worry about this so much because there isn't so much demand in jobs for that field, so there are more candidates for the colleges to choose from.

There are colleges out there that are nearly as cheap as community if you have decent grades. Aurora University in Illinois (a private school!) is nearly the same price for me after their standard GPA scholarships. Do some shopping before you settle.

YMMV but this has been my experience.

I think this video forgets to point out,  or studies don't really consider the point of college. If all colleges were meant to be the same with the same goal in mind, then trade schools wouldn't exist. Most Amercian colleges are not geared to prepare you for the real world. If this was really true, dept would more actively be fought against, becasue what country truly profits if its next generation is in debted to the same country that needs those indebted citizens to get ahead? It doesn't make sense. College is really a place to hone your thinking and make you a critical thinkier of the world you live in. Now if you want to spend 25,000-50,000 per year to do so, or 10,000 or below,  that's your perogative, but what those elite schools have over smaller schools is really, connection. the video hinted at this too, that a reason for more work from an elite school is that you where this schools name like a badge of honor. Thats most likely why you can go to UCLA and see a bunch of freshman wearing HARVARD sewatshirts. With this idea in mind, If you think someone from Harvard says one thing over what someone from UC San Diego says, most would outomatically take the one for Harvard's word as irrefutable text. Not to say that those who go to these schools do not work hard, or are not smart. Many are, but also many aren't at least when is comes to real world application. Such schools have an unfaor advatage, and with the cost of schooling going up, it becomes again a classist thing, where only the rich can go, unless one is lucky enough to get a semi- full ride. So when going to college, not matter where you go, Hone your mind, but also make connections. You may be at a disadvantage that those at Harvard or Oxford, or Yale, or Stanford, but hear is a nicely kept secret. Universities do not define how brilliant you are or how incompetent you are. For me, I got 2010 on my SAT and graduated from community college with a 4.0 GPA. When I tried to apply for transfer to University of Washington, they quickly rejected me. Meanwhile, people with 1800 SAT scores and 3.5 GPA made it in just fine. It's all random. If you get rejected from your dream school, don't get discouraged. It doesn't mean you're dumber than people who do get in. You ALWAYS have opportunities to achieve your dreams. I am going to join the US Army for citizenship and educational benefits. When I leave the army, I'll have a degree in mechanical engineering and aircraft mechanic experience under my belt that will help me get hired at Boeing, Lockheed Martin, Airbus, you name it. My point is, don't believe schools matter. It's your degree, connections and job experience that matters. Someone fresh out of MIT will not get picked over someone who graduated from University of wherever and has been doing the work for years already, or someone who knew the hiring managers there. The only thing that matters is whether you're happy at the end of the day. And immediate success doesn't mean you'll be happy in the future, or vice versa.

A more extreme analogy to comparing the average school's top third to Harvard's bottom third:

A Ph.D. graduate from a crappy school vs. the worst undergraduate student at the best school.

There are students who go to prestigious universities and rather focus on things other than studies instead - in fact, the university culture sometimes encourage it by claiming "there are so many resources at a university, that you're wasting great opportunities if you spend nearly all of your time on studies."

Then there is the fact that not everyone who gets accepted to a top university like Harvard have the necessary background to prepare them for their field. AP Calculus is the highest math offered in High Schools, but math and science topics get much deeper. New students at top universities, too, have to conquer those like anyone else.

If you're talking about more specialized schools like CalTech or MIT, on the other hand, then they do have the advantage of more carefully screening their students for proficiency in particular subjects. Furthermore, fully comprehensive universities offer a very wide range of educational opportunities beyond STEM, and this extra freedom to allow students to explore and learn subjects they may not have proven to be exceptionally good at gives more leeway to fail. But anyone who wants to pursue anything has to start somewhere. Not everyone can hit the ground running on the get go.

Unfortunately college teaches you how you how to get a job, not how to make money. There was a time not so long ago that (believe it or not) people went to college because they had a passion for something and wanted to learn more about it. Not because they were told it was the only way they could get a "good" job. Unfortunately we are almost at the tipping point where too many people have degrees and the jobs that require degrees are not being produced fast enough (economy is not growing at near the rate that colleges are pumping out degrees). Image all of a sudden that everyone in the world suddenly had a degree. Those degrees would be meaningless (from a job seeking standpoint at least).

If you are reading this right now and you are considering taking on student loans to go to college, I would encourage you to think again. More and more people are coming out of college right now with 4 year degrees and are getting the "bad" jobs that people get after they graduate from high school with no degree. I know we have all been indoctrinated to believe that college is the only way because it worked for the baby boomers and it worked for our parents, but times are changing. This phenomena has already been happening in China and it is starting to show here in the US (and other parts of the world) as well.

Great video (as usual), but I think the main takeaway is less clearly stated this time (although it is clearly stated in his comment). In terms of graduation rates, it just comes down to whether or not you are willing to stick it out. If you are, there is no problem with being a small fish in a large pond.

With respect to publications, I think the point is a bit exaggerated. Yes, the 99th percentile at the "worst" schools publish more than the 75th percentile at top schools. However, note that it is at most 2x and as low as 1.25x. Now compare the 98th percentile at those same "worst" schools with the 75th percentile at the top schools. They are about the same. Yes, some people may benefit from being a large fish in a small pond, but it is a very small percent of those people. Overall, those who went to one of the "worst" colleges are most likely to publish less than those who go to top colleges.

ASAP science - as a big fan of your site I find the data in this video either false or extremely misleading.

1. Harvard middle third average SAT score is not 647 - it is much higher around 700. If you profess to have a scientific methodology please cite your data - a copy and paste of links would do.
2. Where did you get graduation rates by SAT? As a student currently in an ivy league school (not Harvard) I've done my research when looking at unis and found no such information. Again, please cite your data.
3. The publication info - the majority of people regardless of school do not wish to go into academia thus the gap between the 99-95 percentile for publications in any school. Along with that, most elite schools have rampant grade inflation where the average gpa is 3.3+ making academia a non priority for most in these schools. Instead most chase engineering/medical/investment banking/consulting careers. A better measure would be career progression 5-10 years down the line after graduation and I can guarantee you a degree from an elite institution pays off even for the bottom third.

Your publication data used as correlation is extremely misleading to future college applicants and I really hope they don't take this video seriously. This coupled with the fact that most elite universities give heavy financial aid or free tuition for many middle class unlike "average" schools.

As a big fan I hope you have more of a scientific outlook on videos such as these as you never know when your video might misguide a teenager.

Does your school matter? Yes. Does it matter because of its reputation? A little. Does it matter because it will make you "smarter"? Not really. A school matters because of the resources and connections available for you, what it can give you, and how it can prepare you, how easy it gets you to the next step.  If you want to be a doctor and you go to a school with  were 60% of its pre-med get accepted in med school, compared to a school with a 95%, both having similar student bodies, there is going to be a difference.The thing is that the schools with the best statistics are those that are called "elite" e.g Ivy schools. Reputation also plays a role, even if smaller, if you hear "a study by  Harvard  University reveals that ...." is going to get more attention than an unknown school. But I do agree, if you are not following any kind of post-undergraduate education or are at the end of your education, a degree in an "elite" school will probably be the same than that of most schools. If you're entering the workforce, your experience and how well you know how to do your  job is what matters!

Assuming I would, hypothetically, graduate with the same degree in the same amount of time, and money were not a factor, I would personally rather go to a top school and be average there than to to a lesser school and do well. The reason is that the connections you can build at these larger, better schools are far superior to those at smaller schools.

Plus, getting the grades isn't as important as it once was when going on to professional schools. From my experience, I have heard that medical schools don't disregard your GPA, but they use the MCAT as the major determining factor. Based on this, I would much rather go to a great school and get a better education even if my grades don't reflect it, than go to a weaker school and get a poor education that won't prepare me for the future.

I am in a relatively small university (about 20k undergrad) because I didn't really have the desire to go to a big school. My school is still every bit as good as the larger schools, but it is not viewed as such. I try to take the most challenging and rigorous courses I can to prepare me for when I have to take the MCAT.

There's a major logical flaw in comparing suicide rates in southern europe to nordic countries.... There's a little something called seasonal effective disorder in northern countries that majorly increases suicide rates. It's why suicide rates in places like Montana and Alaska are so high. Southern areas don't have this issue because they get more sunlight. The lack of sunlight is what causes it. I would know. I'm from Georgia, but I live in Montana. People in Montana are happier, but just like Alaska, yet our suicide and alcohol related deaths are high. I was slightly more depressed in GA, but the lack of light here made it more chronic even though I'm actually happier and have a higher quality of life. lol. Another way to phrase it is that one is my environment of negative people and lower quality of life working against my genetics vs the other is my environment (lack of sunlight) which is much less controllable.

When it comes to (monetary) success in a career, what's far more important than where you go to school is what you study there. Sure, you can get an art degree or one in early childhood development, but you're not getting a good paying job with it. This isn't to say that you shouldn't try to find a career that you'll enjoy, but far too many people seem to think that they'll be making $100k per year by getting just any degree.

If you want the big money, you have to get in the big money fields. Big money is made when the demand for the job exceeds the number of people that can do it. In other words, you're more successful in the fields that are difficult, namely the TE part of STEM (graduate degrees in Science and Mathematics mostly set you up to chase after research grants, unless you specialize in marketable fields).

You should do a Q&A

Assume all of a sample graduate. Of those who graduated form a top university how many found work more quickly out of college? I went to a very well known art school and as a result when I was shopping for work people would say things like, "Don't have much experience... Oh, you went to this place. OK, we'll give you a shot." It worked vastly in my favor and I got way better jobs than many of my peers who had gone to smaller schools simply by name of the school I'd gone to, even though I'd barely passed my final year.

And for the record, most people hadn't actually heard of my specific school. It would have been just as impressive if they had, but it was an art school in Europe and in the US that seemed to carry a lot of weight.

So the name matters, though not necessarily in the way you think.

If you think your school's name will save you from the work that's required of us, you are sorely mistaken. Also, if you think SAT's or GPA has any bearing on how smart you are (or retention rates), again you are mistaken. It's all about what you can "DO" with the information you receive. The amount of family support/pressure you have, whether it's SES or being a 3+ generation student, has more to do with it.

There is something to be said about "academic rigor", but what good is it, if you can't mold your major towards a career focus that fits with what you want to do. That takes proper planning and proper guidance to help you integrate the classroom with the professionals you meet, and the experiential learning you get outside of class. It's a combination of ALL three of those.

The best thing with top schools are the "connections" you make with other students/professionals, and loyalties the alumni have for their school.

I advise college students in career development...and I actually turned down a position at Harvard, to work with 1st generation students.

There are three big problems with this video:

1. While 15.4% of students in the bottom third of their class at Harvard graduate with a degree, not all of this can be attributed to the fact that it is because the smart kids feel inadequate. You are forgetting the fact that the course load and the classes are harder, and on average the kids are spending more hours per week per hour spent in class. It was mentioned in the video that there is prestige in holding a degree at Harvard, and the prestige comes from the academics and the programs offered by the school.

2. It was mentioned that with every 10 point decrease in SAT scores in US schools, degree completion rises by 2%. This is true , but of course, you aren't comparing apples to apples. An engineering degree at MIT does not compare to an engineering degree at a an average US school. Using your numbers, kids have an SAT score of 550 they would on average have a 55% graduation rate versus 15% if they went to Harvard. Again, do not suggest that a lower SAT score will yield beneficial results because you cant compare Engineering degrees from different schools.

3. The study you quoted is incorrect in comparing similar results again. In terms of # of publications submitted, you are suggesting the someone in the top 99 percentile in an average school outperforms the top 75 percentile in prestigious schools. This is very misleading as (taken from the video) the top third students in average schools have an average SAT score of 569. If you were to do the calculation, a top 99 percentile at this school would require you to have an SAT in excess of 650-700. This just reinforces the fact that SAT score is directly linked to performance in academia.

You suggest the formula form success is mixed, when in reality its not. This video does not the stress the importance of going to average schools because all it shows is that you require to be in the top 1% of students to be comparable to the above average harvard student. If anything, that would make me feel even more insignificant if academic success (in terms of publications after post doc) was my only concern. This video just shows that if you want a generic STEM degree, and you dont care about where you work/funding for grants, you should just go to an average school.

As an Oxford graduate I have first-hand experience so I can claim that...the actual quality of education you get is pretty much the same as anywhere else. Yeah, your lecturers are experts in their field but they can only teach you material starting from the bottom, and will never be able to go in-depth (that's what a PhD/DPhil is for). If you're certain of your abilities and you REALLY want your certificate to say Oxford, Cambridge, Harvard, MIT, etc then go for it but in practice, most universities will give you roughly the same education.

P.S: Oxford in particular is a stickler for compulsory odd traditions so if you don't want to do your exams while looking like a Hogwarts student, you'd better apply to Cambridge instead.

See, starting High school (age ~12) there are 5 levels of education. The highest scoring 20% get the toughest education brain-wise, the lowest scoring 20% receive education more oriented towards manual labour. After High school this diversion is continued and the highest scoring 20% go to Universities (which, in the Netherlands, is a term heavily protected by the law – an education institution needs to abide strict rules before they can call themselves a University) to become doctors or researchers, the lowest scoring 60% goes to "MBO" (which has various levels on its own but I'm not familiar with those), there, they too receive a job specific education (e.g., bodyguards, machine operators, assistants).

Either way, what you see within these levels is that the lowest scoring of the 20% highest scoring can still feel incredibly dumb, simply because they are fully segregated from the other, even less brain-capable (couldn't find a better word) 80%.

Some of this isnt applicable in the way described. In the little fish big pond example, the SAT is curved based off the global stats. However, the local exams and midterms are curved based off the people who take them, being only that school.  The competition actually matters because if the exam was taken at a more prestigious school like harvard, the same number of questions right would actually give you a worse score than if you got the exact same questions right at a worse school, so in other words, the effect is not only psychological, its physical.
